<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In addition, Flash Partners expects to secure additional
    equipment lease facilities over time.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Guarantees</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Indemnification Agreements.</I>&#160;&#160;The Company has
    agreed to indemnify suppliers and customers for alleged patent
    infringement. The scope of such indemnity varies, but may, in
    some instances, include indemnification for damages and
    expenses, including attorneys&#146; fees. The Company may
    periodically engage in litigation as a result of these
    indemnification obligations. The Company&#146;s insurance
    policies exclude coverage for third-party claims for patent
    infringement. Although the liability is not remote, the nature
    of the patent infringement indemnification obligations prevents
    the Company from making a reasonable estimate of the maximum
    potential amount it could be required to pay to its suppliers
    and customers. Historically, the Company has not made any
    significant indemnification payments under any such agreements.
    As of January&#160;1, 2006, no amount has been accrued in the
    accompanying condensed consolidated financial statements with
    respect to these indemnification guarantees.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As permitted under Delaware law and the Company&#146;s charter
    and bylaws, the Company has agreements whereby it indemnifies
    certain of its officers and each of its directors for certain
    events or occurrences while the officer or director is, or was,
    serving at the Company&#146;s request in such capacity. The term
    of the indemnification period is for the officer&#146;s or
    director&#146;s lifetime. The maximum potential amount of future
    payments the Company could be required to make under these
    indemnification agreements is unlimited; however, the Company
    has a Director and Officer insurance policy that may reduce its
    exposure and enable it to recover all or a portion of any future
    amounts paid. As a result of its insurance policy coverage, the
    Company believes the estimated fair value of these
    indemnification agreements is minimal. The Company has no
    liabilities recorded for these agreements as of January&#160;1,
    2006 or January&#160;2, 2005, as this liability is not
    reasonably estimable even though liability under these
    agreements is not remote.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company and Toshiba have agreed to mutually contribute to,
    and indemnify each other and Flash Partners for, environmental
    remediation costs or liability resulting from Flash
    Partners&#146; manufacturing operations in certain
    circumstances. The Company and Toshiba have also entered into a
    Patent Indemnification Agreement under which in many cases the
    Company will share in the expenses associated with the defense
    and cost of settlement associated with such claims. This
    agreement provides limited protection for the Company against
    third-party claims that NAND flash memory products manufactured
    and sold by Flash Partners infringe third-party patents. In
    2004, the Company and Toshiba each engaged consultants to
    perform a review of the existing environmental conditions at the
    site of the facility in which Flash Partners operations are
    located to establish a baseline for evaluating future
    environmental conditions. The Company has not made any
    indemnification payments under any such agreements and as of
    January&#160;1, 2006, no amounts have been accrued in the
    accompanying condensed consolidated financial statements with
    respect to these indemnification guarantees.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    See also &#147;Off Balance Sheet Liabilities&#148; above
    regarding Flash Partner equipment lease facilities.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Litigation</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company is involved in a number of lawsuits, including,
    among others, cases involving the Company&#146;s patents and the
    patents of third parties. The Company cannot reasonably estimate
    a probable loss in any of these matters. Some of the actions
    seek injunctions against the Company&#146;s sale of its products
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">and/or</FONT>
    substantial monetary damages, which if granted or awarded could
    have a material adverse effect on the Company&#146;s business,
    financial condition and results of operations.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    F-23
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Litigation is subject to inherent risks and uncertainties that
    may cause actual results to differ materially from the
    Company&#146;s expectations. Factors that could cause litigation
    results to differ include, but are not limited to, the discovery
    of previously unknown facts, changes in the law or in the
    interpretation of laws, and uncertainties associated with the
    judicial decision-making process. If the Company receives an
    adverse judgment in any litigation, it could be required to pay
    substantial damages
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">and/or</FONT> cease
    the manufacture, use and sale of products. Litigation, including
    intellectual property litigation, can be complex, can extend for
    a protracted period of time, and can be expensive. Litigation
    initiated by the Company could also result in counter-claims
    against it, which could increase the costs associated with the
    litigation and result in the Company&#146;s payment of damages
    or other judgments against it.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company has been subject to, and expects to continue to be
    subject to, claims and legal proceedings regarding alleged
    infringement by the Company of the patents, trademarks and other
    intellectual property rights of third parties. From time to time
    the Company has sued, and may in the future sue, third parties
    in order to protect its intellectual property rights. Parties
    that the Company has sued and that it may sue for patent
    infringement may counter-sue the Company for infringing their
    patents. If the Company was held to infringe the intellectual
    property of others, the Company may need to spend significant
    resources to develop non-infringing technology or obtain
    licenses from third parties, but the Company may not be able to
    develop such technology or acquire such licenses on terms
    acceptable to it or at all.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    From time to time the Company agrees to indemnify certain of its
    suppliers and customers for alleged patent infringement. The
    scope of such indemnity varies but may in some instances include
    indemnification for damages and expenses, including
    attorneys&#146; fees. The Company may from time to time be
    engaged in litigation as a result of such indemnification
    obligations. Third-party claims for patent infringement are
    excluded from coverage under the Company&#146;s insurance
    policies. Any future obligation to indemnify the Company&#146;s
    customers or suppliers may have a material adverse effect on the
    Company&#146;s business, financial condition and results of
    operations.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Legal
    Proceedings</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On or about August&#160;3, 2001, the Lemelson Medical,
    Education&#160;&#38; Research Foundation, or Lemelson
    Foundation, filed a complaint for patent infringement against
    the Company and four other defendants. The suit, captioned
    Lemelson Medical, Education,&#160;&#38; Research Foundation,
    Limited Partnership vs. Broadcom Corporation, et&#160;al., Civil
    Case No.&#160;CIV01 1440PHX HRH, was filed in the United States
    District Court, District of Arizona. On November&#160;13, 2001,
    the Lemelson Foundation filed an amended complaint, which made
    the same substantive allegations against the Company but named
    more than twenty five additional defendants. The amended
    complaint alleges that the Company, and the other defendants,
    have infringed patents held by the Lemelson Foundation
    pertaining to bar code scanning technology. By its complaint,
    the Lemelson Foundation requests that the Company be enjoined
    from its allegedly infringing activities and seeks unspecified
    damages. The case as to the Company was stayed pending the
    outcome of litigation in the District Court of Nevada related to
    the same Lemelson bar code scanning patents asserted against the
    Company. In early 2004, the Nevada Court ruled that the Lemelson
    bar code patents (as well as other Lemelson patents) were
    invalid, not infringed and unenforceable. The Nevada
    Court&#146;s findings were thereafter affirmed by the Federal
    Circuit. Based on the Federal Circuit&#146;s affirmance, the
    Lemelson Foundation moved to dismiss with prejudice all claims
    against the Company, and that request for dismissal has been
    granted.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On October&#160;31, 2001, the Company filed a complaint for
    patent infringement in the United States District Court for the
    Northern District of California against Memorex Products, Inc.,
    Pretec Electronics Corporation, Ritek Corporation, and Power
    Quotient International Co., Ltd. In the suit, captioned SanDisk
    Corp.&#160;v. Memorex Products, Inc., et&#160;al., Civil Case
    No.&#160;CV 01 4063 VRW, the Company seeks damages and
    injunctions against these companies from making, selling,
    importing or using flash memory cards that infringe its
    U.S.&#160;Patent No.&#160;5,602,987. The court granted summary
    judgment of non-infringement in favor of defendants Ritek,
    Pretec and Memorex and entered judgment on May&#160;17, 2004. On
    June&#160;2, 2004, the Company filed a notice of appeal of the
    summary judgment rulings to the United States Court of Appeals
    for the Federal Circuit. On July&#160;8, 2005, the Federal
    Circuit held in favor of SanDisk, vacating the judgment of
    non-infringement and remanding the case back to district court.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    F-24
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On or about June&#160;9, 2003, the Company received written
    notice from Infineon Technologies AG, or Infineon, that it
    believes the Company has infringed its U.S.&#160;Patent
    No.&#160;5,726,601 (the &#146;601 patent). On June&#160;24,
    2003, the Company filed a complaint against Infineon for a
    declaratory judgment of patent non-infringement and invalidity
    regarding the &#146;601 patent in the United States District
    Court for the Northern District of California, captioned SanDisk
    Corporation&#160;v. Infineon Technologies AG, a German
    corporation, et&#160;al., Civil Case No.&#160;C 03 02931 BZ. On
    October&#160;6, 2003, Infineon filed an answer and counterclaim:
    (a)&#160;denying that the Company is entitled to the declaration
    sought by the the Company&#146;s complaint; (b)&#160;requesting
    that the Company be adjudged to have infringed, actively induced
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">and/or</FONT>
    contributed to the infringement of the &#146;601 patent and an
    additional patent, U.S.&#160;Patent No.&#160;4,841,222 (the
    &#146;222 patent). On August&#160;12, 2004, Infineon filed an
    amended counterclaim for patent infringement alleging that the
    Company infringed U.S.&#160;Patent Nos. 6,026,002 (the &#146;002
    patent); 5,041,894 (the &#146;894 patent); and 6,226,219 (the
    &#146;219 patent), and omitting the &#146;601 and &#146;222
    patents. On August&#160;18, 2004, the Company filed an amended
    complaint against Infineon for a declaratory judgment of patent
    non-infringement and invalidity regarding the &#146;002,
    &#146;894, and &#146;219 patents. On February&#160;9, 2006, the
    Company filed a second amended complaint to include claims for
    declaratory judgment that the &#146;002, &#146;894 and &#146;219
    patents are unenforceable.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On October&#160;2, 2003, a purported shareholder class action
    lawsuit was filed on behalf of United States holders of ordinary
    shares of Tower as of the close of business on April&#160;1,
    2002 in the United States District Court for the Southern
    District of New York. The suit, captioned Philippe de Vries,
    Julia Frances Dunbar De Vries Trust, et&#160;al.,&#160;v. Tower
    Semiconductor Ltd., et&#160;al., Civil Case No.&#160;03 CV 4999,
    was filed against Tower and a number of its shareholders and
    directors, including the Company and Dr.&#160;Harari, who is a
    Tower board member, and asserts claims arising under
    Sections&#160;14(a) and 20(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of
    1934, as amended, and Rule&#160;14a 9 promulgated there under.
    The lawsuit alleges that Tower and certain of its directors made
    false and misleading statements in a proxy solicitation to Tower
    shareholders regarding a proposed amendment to a contract
    between Tower and certain of its shareholders, including the
    Company. The plaintiffs are seeking unspecified damages and
    attorneys&#146; and experts&#146; fees and expenses. On
    August&#160;19, 2004, the court granted the Company and the
    other defendants&#146; motion to dismiss the complaint in its
    entirety with prejudice. On September&#160;29, 2004, plaintiffs
    appealed the dismissal to the United States Court of Appeals for
    the Second Circuit.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On February&#160;20, 2004, the Company and a number of other
    manufacturers of flash memory products were sued in the Superior
    Court of the State of California for the City and County of
    San&#160;Francisco in a purported consumer class action
    captioned Willem Vroegh et&#160;al.&#160;v. Dane Electric Corp.
    USA, et&#160;al., Civil Case No.&#160;GCG 04 428953, alleging
    false advertising, unfair business practices, breach of
    contract, fraud, deceit, misrepresentation and violation of the
    California Consumers Legal Remedy Act. The lawsuit purports to
    be on behalf of a class of purchasers of flash memory products
    and claims that the defendants overstated the size of the memory
    storage capabilities of such products. The lawsuit seeks
    restitution, injunction and damages in an unspecified amount.
    The parties have reached a settlement of the case, which is
    pending court approval.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On October&#160;15, 2004, the Company filed a complaint for
    patent infringement and declaratory judgment of non-infringement
    and patent invalidity against STMicroelectronics N.V. and
    STMicroelectronics, Inc. in the United States District Court for
    the Northern District of California, captioned SanDisk
    Corporation&#160;v. STMicroelectronics, Inc., et&#160;al., Civil
    Case No.&#160;C 04 04379JF. The complaint alleges that
    STMicro&#146;s products infringe one of the Company&#146;s
    U.S.&#160;patents and seeks damages and an injunction. The
    complaint further seeks a declaratory judgment that the Company
    does not infringe several of STMicro&#146;s U.S.&#160;patents.
    By order dated January&#160;4, 2005, the court stayed the
    Company&#146;s claim that STMicro infringes its patent pending
    an outcome in the ITC investigation initiated on
    November&#160;15, 2004 (discussed below). On January&#160;20,
    2005, the court issued an order granting STMicro&#146;s motion
    to dismiss the declaratory judgment causes of action. The
    Company has appealed this decision to the U.S.&#160;Court of
    Appeals for the Federal Circuit. The remainder of the case,
    including the Company&#146;s infringement claim against STMicro,
    is stayed pending the outcome of the appeal.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On February&#160;4, 2005, STMicro filed two complaints for
    patent infringement against the Company in the United States
    District Court for the Eastern District of Texas, captioned
    STMicroelectronics, Inc.&#160;v. SanDisk Corporation, Civil Case
    No.&#160;4 05CV44, and STMicroelectronics, Inc.&#160;v. SanDisk
    Corporation, Civil Case No.&#160;4 05CV45, respectively. The
    complaints seek damages and injunctions against unspecified
    SanDisk products. On April&#160;22,
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    F-25
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    2005, the Company filed counterclaims on two patents against
    STMicroelectronics N.V. and STMicroelectronics, Inc. in the
    Civil Case 4-05CV45 proceeding. The counterclaims seek damages
    and injunctive relief against STMicroelectronics N.V. and
    STMicroelectronics, Inc. flash memory products.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On October&#160;15, 2004, the Company filed a complaint under
    Section&#160;337 of the Tariff Act of 1930 (as amended) titled,
    &#147;In the matter of certain NAND flash memory circuits and
    products containing same&#148; in the United States
    International Trade Commission, naming STMicroelectronics N.V.
    and STMicroelectronics, Inc. (&#147;STMicro&#148;) as
    respondents. In the complaint, the Company alleges that
    STMicro&#146;s NAND flash memory infringes U.S.&#160;Patent
    No.&#160;5,172,338 (the &#146;338 patent), and seek an order
    excluding their products from importation into the United
    States. In the complaint, the Company alleges that
    STMicro&#146;s NAND flash memory infringes the &#146;338 patent
    and seeks an order excluding their products from importation
    into the United States. On November&#160;15, 2004, the ITC
    instituted an investigation pursuant to 19&#160;U.S.C.
    Section&#160;1337 against STMicro in response to the
    Company&#146;s complaint. A hearing was held from August 1-8,
    2005. On October&#160;19, 2005, the Administrative Law Judge
    issued an initial determination confirming the validity and
    enforceability of the Company&#146;s United States Patent
    5,172,338 (the &#146;338 patent) by rejecting STMicro&#146;s
    claims that the patent was invalidated by prior art. The initial
    determination, however, found that STMicro&#146;s NAND flash
    memory chips did not infringe three claims of the &#146;338
    patent. On October&#160;31, 2005, the Company filed a petition
    with the International Trade Commission to review and reverse
    the finding of non-infringement. Also, on October&#160;31, 2005,
    STMicro filed a petition for review with the International Trade
    Commission to review and reverse the finding that the patent was
    valid and enforceable. On December&#160;6, 2005, the ITC issued
    its decision. The ITC declined to review the finding of
    non-infringement, and, after reviewing the finding of validity,
    declined to take any position on the issue of validity. The
    Company is appealing the ITC&#146;s decision to the
    U.S.&#160;Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On October&#160;14, 2005, STMicroelectronics, Inc. filed a
    complaint against the Company and the Company&#146;s CEO Eli
    Harari, in the Superior Court of the State of California for the
    County of Alameda, captioned STMicroelectronics, Inc.&#160;v.
    Harari, Case No.&#160;HG 05237216. The complaint alleges that
    STMicroelectronics,Inc., as the successor to Wafer Scale
    Integration, Inc.&#146;s (&#147;WSI&#148;) legal rights, has an
    ownership interest in several SanDisk patents that issued from
    applications filed by Dr.&#160;Harari, a former WSI employee.
    The complaint seeks the assignment of certain inventions and
    patents conceived of by Harari as well as damages in an
    unspecified amount. On November&#160;15, 2005, Harari and the
    Company removed the case to the U.S.&#160;District Court for the
    Northern District of California, where it was assigned case
    number C05-04691. On November&#160;23, 2005, Harari and the
    Company filed counterclaims, asserting the Company&#146;s (i.e.
    SanDisk&#146;s) ownership of the patents and applications raised
    in the complaint. On December&#160;13, 2005, STMicroelectronics,
    Inc. filed a motion to remand the case back to the Superior
    Court of Alameda County. That motion remains pending.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On December&#160;6, 2005, the Company filed a complaint for
    patent infringement in the United States District Court for the
    Northern District of California against STMicroelectronics, Inc.
    and STMicroelectronics, NV (&#147;STMicro&#148;) (Case
    No.&#160;C0505021 JF). In the suit, the Company seeks damages
    and injunctions against STMicro from making, selling, importing
    or using flash memory chips or products that infringe the
    Company&#146;s U.S.&#160;Patent No.&#160;5,991,517. The case is
    presently stayed, pending the termination of the ITC
    investigation instituted February&#160;8, 2006, discussed below.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On January&#160;11, 2006, the Company filed a complaint for
    patent infringement in the United States District Court for the
    Northern District of California against STMicro (Case
    No.C06-00194 JF). In the suit, the Company seeks damages and
    injunctions against STMicro from making, selling, importing or
    using flash memory chips or products that infringe the
    Company&#146;s U.S.&#160;Patent No.&#160;6,542,956. The case is
    presently stayed, pending the termination of the ITC
    investigation instituted February&#160;8, 2006, discussed below.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On January&#160;10, 2006, the Company filed a complaint under
    Section&#160;337 of the Tariff Act of 1930 (as amended) titled,
    &#147;In the matter of certain NAND flash memory circuits and
    products containing same&#148; in the ITC, naming STMicro as
    respondents. In the complaint, the Company alleges that:
    (i)&#160;STMicro&#146;s NOR flash memory infringes the &#146;338
    patent; (ii)&#160;STMicro&#146;s NAND flash memory infringes
    U.S.&#160;Patent No.&#160;6,542,956; and
    (iii)&#160;STMicro&#146;s NOR flash memory and NAND flash memory
    infringe U.S.&#160;Patent No.&#160;5,991,517. The complaint
    seeks an order
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    F-26
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    excluding STMicro&#146;s NOR and NAND flash memory products from
    importation into the United States. The ITC instituted an
    investigation, based on the Company&#146;s complaint, on
    February&#160;8, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On or about July&#160;15, 2005, Societa&#146; Italiana Per Lo
    Sviluppo Dell&#146;electtronica, S.I.Sv.El., S.p.A.,
    (&#147;Sisvel&#148;) filed suit against the Company and others
    in the district court of the Netherlands in The Hague in a case
    captioned Societa&#146; Italiana Per Lo Sviluppo
    Dell&#146;electtronica, S.I.Sv.El., S.p.A. adverse to SanDisk
    International Sales, Moduslink B.V. and UPS SCS (Nederland)
    B.V., Case No.&#160;999.131.1804. Sisvel alleges that certain of
    the Company&#146;s MP3 products infringe three European patents
    of which Sisvel claims to be a licensee with the right to bring
    suit. Sisvel seeks an injunction and unspecified damages. Sisvel
    has previously publicly indicated that it will license these and
    other patents under reasonable and nondiscriminatory terms, and
    it has specifically offered the Company a license under the
    patents. The Company has submitted pleadings asking the court to
    strike Sisvel&#146;s pleadings as legally insufficient and
    seeking other procedural relief. The court is still addressing
    these procedural matters and the Company will not be required to
    answer on the substance of Sisvel&#146;s claim until April 2006
    at the earliest.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In a related action, on February&#160;21, 2006, the Company
    filed an action in the English High Court, Chancery Division,
    Patents Court, in London, against the owners of the patents
    Sisvel has asserted against the Company. The case is SanDisk
    Corporation&#160;v. Koninklijke Philips Electronics N.V. (a
    Dutch corporation), France T&#233;l&#233;com (a French
    corporation), T&#233;l&#233;diffusion de France S.A. (a French
    corporation), and Institut f&#252;r Rundfunktechnik GmbH (a
    German corporation), Case No.&#160;HC06 C 00615. In this action,
    the Company seeks a declaration that the patents asserted by
    Sisvel (as well as other patents owned by Philips and the other
    defendants) are invalid because they fail to properly claim
    anything new within the meaning of the European Patent
    Convention and because certain of them fail to comply with other
    requirements of the Convention. The defendants in that case are
    required to appear and announce their intention to defend on or
    about March&#160;7, 2006. The defendants&#146; formal defense
    will be due in early April 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In another related action, on March&#160;9, 2006, the Company
    filed an action in the English High Court, Chancery Division,
    Patents Court, in London, against Sisvel and the owners of the
    patents Sisvel has asserted against the Company in the
    Netherlands. The case is SanDisk Corporation&#160;v. Koninklijke
    Philips Electronics N.V. (a Dutch corporation), France
    T&#233;l&#233;com (a French corporation),
    T&#233;l&#233;diffusion de France S.A. (a French corporation),
    Institut f&#252;r Rundfunktechnik GmbH (a German corporation)
    and Societa&#146; Italiana Per Lo Sviluppo
    Dell&#146;electtronica, S.I.Sv.El., S.p.A., Case
    No.&#160;HC06C00835. In this action, the Company seeks a
    declaration of non-infringement of the patents asserted by
    Sisvel in connection with SanDisk&#146;s MP3 products. The
    Company also seeks a declaration that the patents are not
    &#147;essential&#148; to the technology of MP3 players, as
    Sisvel presently contends in the case filed in the Netherlands.
    The defendants are required to appear and announce their
    intention to defend at the end of March, 2006. The
    defendants&#146; formal defense will be due in early May 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On or about January&#160;12, 2006, the Company was served with a
    complaint in an action filed by SoftVault Systems, Inc. in the
    United States District Court for the Eastern District of Texas.
    The case is SoftVault Systems, Inc.&#160;v. Yahoo! Inc.,
    Microsoft Corporation, Napster, Inc., Creative Labs, Inc., Dell
    USA LP, Gateway, Inc., iriver America, Inc., Samsung Electronics
    America, Inc., Toshiba America Consumer Products, L.L.C.,
    Digital Networks North America, Inc., Palm, Inc., Audiovox
    Corporation, SanDisk Corporation, and Thomson Inc., Case
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">No.&#160;2:06-cv-00017-LED.</FONT>
    SoftVault accuses the Company, and others, of infringing its
    patents through the use of Microsoft&#146;s Windows Digital
    Rights Management technology. The Company is reviewing the
    matter and preparing its answer. The Company intends to
    vigorously defend against this action.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Contingencies</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Lee and Li Settlement.</I>&#160;&#160;Effective as of
    November&#160;14, 2003, the Company and Lee and Li entered into
    a Settlement and General Release Agreement, or Settlement
    Agreement, concerning UMC shares embezzled by a former employee
    of that firm. Pursuant to the Settlement Agreement, the Company
    received a cash payment of $20.0&#160;million at the time of
    signing. In addition, Lee and Li agreed to pay the Company
    $45.0&#160;million (inclusive of interest $47.9&#160;million)
    over four years in sixteen quarterly installments. Of this
    amount $11.3&#160;million was classified
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    F-27
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    as current other assets at January&#160;1, 2006 and
    January&#160;2, 2005, and $11.3&#160;million and
    $22.5&#160;million was classified as non-current other assets in
    the accompanying consolidated balance sheets as of
    January&#160;1, 2006 and January&#160;2, 2005, respectively.
    These amounts are secured by irrevocable standby letters of
    credit issued by the International Commercial Bank of China, or
    ICBC. Further, Lee and Li extended a credit to the Company in
    the amount of $18.3&#160;million to be applied against future
    legal services provided by Lee and Li and to be spread equally
    over 18&#160;years. This amount was reduced by $6.2&#160;million
    as a result of a recovery from a third party brokerage firm in
    2004. As a result of the recovery, the credit has been reduced
    to approximately $12&#160;million to be spread equally over
    approximately 12&#160;years. If any of the stolen assets are
    recovered, the net amount after recovery of expenses will be
    split between the Company and Lee and Li, in specified
    proportions until the Company receives a maximum amount of
    $106.6&#160;million, including all amounts described above.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Contractual
    Obligations and Off Balance Sheet Arrangements</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following summarizes the Company&#146;s contractual cash
    obligations, commitments and off balance sheet arrangements at
    January&#160;1, 2006, and the effect such obligations are
    expected to have on its liquidity and cash flows in future
    periods (in thousands).
</DIV>

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to

    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (1) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In January 2006, the Company incurred additional property lease
    obligations related to its lease of 3 buildings in Milpitas,
    California and from its acquisition of Matrix
    Semiconductor,&#160;Inc. The Company&#146;s additional property
    lease obligation subsequent to January&#160;1, 2006 will be
    $2.7&#160;million, $9.5&#160;million, $10.3&#160;million and
    $17.2&#160;million for less than 1&#160;year, 2-3&#160;years,
    3-5&#160;years and over 5&#160;years, respectively. See
    Note&#160;12, &#147;Subsequent Events.&#148;</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (2) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    In January 2006, Flash Partners drew down the entire December
    2005 lease facility which resulted in an increase of the
    Company&#146;s guarantee of 17.5&#160;billion Japanese yen, or
    approximately $148&#160;million based upon the exchange rate at
    January&#160;1, 2006. Lease payments are due quarterly and will
    be completed in 2011. The Company&#146;s additional lease
    commitment related to this lease will be $28.2&#160;million,
    $43.1&#160;million, $41.6&#160;million and $35.5&#160;million
    for less than 1&#160;year, 2-3&#160;years, 3-5&#160;years and
    over 5&#160;years, respectively. See Note&#160;12,
    &#147;Subsequent Events.&#148;</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (3) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Includes Toshiba foundries, FlashVision, Flash Partners, related
    parties vendors and other silicon sources vendors purchase
    commitments.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (4) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Amounts are denominated in Japanese yen, are subject to
    fluctuation in exchange rates prior to payment and have been
    translated using the exchange rate at January&#160;1, 2006.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (5) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The Company&#146;s contingent indemnification obligation is
    8.8&#160;billion Japanese yen, or approximately $75&#160;million
    based upon the exchange rate at January&#160;1, 2006.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (6) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The Company&#146;s guarantee obligation, net of cumulative lease
    payments, is 24.0&#160;billion Japanese yen, or approximately
    $203&#160;million based upon the exchange rate at
    January&#160;1, 2006.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company&#146;s objective for holding derivatives is to
    minimize the material risks associated with non-functional
    currency transactions and does not enter into derivatives for
    speculative or trading purposes. The Company&#146;s derivative
    instruments are recorded at fair value on the balance sheet with
    changes in fair value recorded in other income (expense). The
    Company had foreign currency exchange contract lines available
    in the amount of $1.18&#160;billion at January&#160;1, 2006 to
    enter into foreign currency forward contracts. As of
    January&#160;1, 2006, the Company had foreign currency forward
    contracts in place with a notional amount of 3.95&#160;billion
    Japanese yen, or approximately $34&#160;million based upon the
    exchange rate at January&#160;1, 2006. The fair value of these
    foreign currency forward contracts as of January&#160;1, 2006
    were immaterial. The realized gains and losses on foreign
    currency forward contracts for the fiscal year ended
    January&#160;1, 2006 was immaterial.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    F-29
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The tax benefits associated with the exercise of stock options
    reduced taxes payable by $95.6&#160;million in 2005 and reduced
    taxes payable by $17.9&#160;million in 2004. Such benefits are
    credited to capital in excess of par value when realized.
</DIV>

    Deferred income taxes reflect the net tax effects of temporary
    differences between the carrying amounts of assets and
    liabilities for financial reporting purposes and the amounts
    used for income tax return reporting purposes.

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    At January&#160;1, 2006, a $14.9&#160;million valuation
    allowance was provided based, more likely than not, on the
    Company&#146;s inability to recognize a tax benefit from certain
    write downs on its investment in Tower. At January&#160;2, 2005,
    a $12.3&#160;million valuation allowance was provided based on
    the net deferred tax assets on the same investment.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During the current and prior years, the Company has not made a
    determination to permanently reinvest earnings of its foreign
    subsidiaries.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Note&#160;7:&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Strategic
    Investments</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>UMC.</I>&#160;&#160;The Company maintains an investment
    position in United Microelectronics Corporation, or UMC, one of
    its suppliers of wafers for its controller components, on the
    cost basis of accounting. As of January&#160;1, 2006, the
    Company owned 24.5&#160;million UMC shares with a cost basis of
    $13.4&#160;million and a fair market value of $13.9&#160;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Tower Semiconductor.</I>&#160;&#160;The Company owns
    approximately 15% of the outstanding shares of Tower
    Semiconductor Ltd., or Tower, one of its suppliers of wafers for
    its controller components. The Company has sourced controller
    wafers from Tower since the third quarter of fiscal 2003. As of
    January&#160;1, 2006, the Company owned approximately
    10.2&#160;million Tower shares with a carrying value and market
    value of $12.9&#160;million and $14.8&#160;million,
    respectively, a warrant to purchase 0.4&#160;million Tower
    ordinary shares at an exercise price of $7.50&#160;per share,
    with a carrying value of zero and Tower prepaid wafer credits
    with a carrying value of zero. In fiscal 2005, the Company
    recorded an unrealized loss of $1.1&#160;million through OCI on
    its Tower investment to bring the carrying value of the Tower
    shares to market value. In December 2005, the Company invested
    $3.5&#160;million in a Tower convertible debenture offering.
    Conversion is not restricted. See Note&#160;10, &#147;Related
    Parties&#160;&#151;&#160;Tower.&#148;
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>U3, LLC.</I>&#160;&#160;In the first quarter of fiscal 2005,
    the Company entered into an agreement with M-Systems, Inc., or
    M-Systems, under which they formed U3, LLC. U3, LLC was founded
    to develop a platform for which software developers can
    transform USB drives from a simple mass storage device to a
    platform for on-the-go computing. The Company and M-Systems each
    own 50% of U3, LLC. The Company is entitled to half of any
    residual gains. However, as the Company will provide greater
    than 50% of the U3, LLC financial support, it would receive more
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    F-31
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    than half of any residual losses with respect to the U3, LLC
    entity. As a result, U3, LLC is considered a variable interest
    entity and the Company is the primary beneficiary. The Company
    has consolidated the statement of financial position and the
    results of operations for the year ended January&#160;1, 2006.
    The Company&#146;s total investment in U3 as of January&#160;1,
    2006 was $2.8&#160;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Note&#160;8:&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Stockholders&#146;
    Rights Plan</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On September&#160;15, 2003, the Company amended its existing
    stockholder rights plan to terminate the rights issued under
    that rights plan, and the Company adopted a new rights plan.
    Under the new rights plan, rights were distributed as a dividend
    at the rate of one right for each share of common stock of the
    Company held by stockholders of record as of the close of
    business on September&#160;&#160;25, 2003. The rights will
    expire on April&#160;28, 2007 unless redeemed or exchanged.
    Under the new rights agreement and after giving effect to the
    Company&#146;s stock dividend effected on February&#160;18,
    2004, each right will, under the circumstances described below,
    entitle the registered holder to buy one two-hundredths of a
    share of Series&#160;A Junior Participating Preferred Stock for
    $225.00. The rights will become exercisable only if a person or
    group acquires beneficial ownership of 15% or more of the
    Company&#146;s common stock or commences a tender offer or
    exchange offer upon consummation of which such person or group
    would beneficially own 15% or more of the Company&#146;s common
    stock.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

    per share include the dilutive effects of stock options,
    warrants, and convertible securities. Options and warrants to
    purchase 97,753, 6,140,781 and 1,253,457&#160;shares of common
    stock were outstanding during 2005, 2004
</DIV>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    and 2003, respectively, but have been omitted from the diluted
    earnings per share calculation because the options&#146;
    exercise price was greater than the average market price of the
    common shares and, therefore the effect would be antidilutive.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="9%"></TD>
    <TD width="91%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Note&#160;10:&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Related
    Parties</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company owns approximately 15% of the outstanding shares of
    Tower, prepaid wafer credits issued by Tower convertible debt
    and a warrant to purchase Tower ordinary shares. The
    Company&#146;s Chief Executive Officer is a member of the Tower
    board of directors. The Company paid Tower approximately
    $31.3&#160;million and $28.4&#160;million fiscal years ended
    January&#160;1, 2006 and January&#160;&#160;2, 2005,
    respectively, for the purchase of controller wafers and related
    non-recurring engineering, or NRE. These purchases of controller
    wafers are ultimately reflected as a component of the
    Company&#146;s cost of product revenues. At January&#160;1, 2006
    and January&#160;2, 2005, the Company had amounts payable to
    Tower of approximately $2.4&#160;million and $7.6&#160;million,
    respectively, related to the purchase of controller wafers and
    related NRE. See Note&#160;7, &#147;Strategic
    Investments&#160;&#151;&#160;Tower Semiconductor.&#148;
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The former President and Chief Executive Officer of Flextronics
    International, Ltd., or Flextronics, has served on the
    Company&#146;s Board of Directors since September 2003. For the
    years ended January&#160;1, 2006 and January&#160;2, 2005, the
    Company recorded revenues related to Flextronics and its
    affiliates of $25.3&#160;million and $4.3&#160;million,
    respectively, and at January&#160;1, 2006 and January&#160;2,
    2005, the Company had amounts receivable from Flextronics and
    its affiliates of $12.5&#160;million and $2.7&#160;million,
    respectively. In addition, the Company paid Flextronics and its
    affiliates $40.2&#160;million and $37.4&#160;million for the
    years ended January&#160;1, 2006 and January&#160;2, 2005,
    respectively, for card assembly and testing which are ultimately
    reflected as a component of the Company&#146;s cost of product
    revenues. At January&#160;1, 2006 and January&#160;2, 2005, the
    Company had amounts payable to Flextronics and its affiliates of
    approximately $5.4&#160;million and $2.0&#160;million,
    respectively, for these services.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company and M-Systems entered into an agreement to
    form&#160;U3, LLC, an entity to develop and market a next
    generation platform for universal serial bus flash drives. See
    Note&#160;7, &#147;Strategic Investments&#160;&#151;&#160;U3,
    LLC.&#148;
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    See also Note&#160;11 for disclosures related to investments in
    Toshiba ventures.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="9%"></TD>
    <TD width="91%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Note&#160;11:&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Investment
    in Toshiba Ventures</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Toshiba</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company entered into agreements with Toshiba; under which
    FlashVision and Flash Partners were formed to purchase from
    Toshiba advanced NAND flash memory wafers (see also Note&#160;5,
    &#147;Commitments, Contingencies and Guarantees&#148;). During
    fiscal 2005, the Company purchased approximately
    $39.1&#160;million of capital equipment which is located in
    Toshiba&#146;s Yokkaichi operations. In return, the Company will
    receive 100% of the output from this equipment. The Company
    purchased NAND flash memory wafers from FlashVision, Flash
    Partners and Toshiba, purchased capital equipment from
    FlashVision, made payments for shared research and development
    expenses, made loans to FlashVision and made investments in
    Flash Partners totaling approximately $571.7&#160;million,
    $516.6&#160;million and $223.5&#160;million for the comparable
    periods of fiscal 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively. The
    purchases of NAND flash memory wafers are ultimately reflected
    as a component of the Company&#146;s cost of product revenues.
    At January&#160;&#160;1, 2006 and January&#160;2, 2005, the
    Company had accounts payable balances due to FlashVision of
    $23.0&#160;million and $30.7&#160;million, respectively,
    balances due to Flash Partners of $27.0&#160;million and zero,
    respectively, and balances due to Toshiba of $11.7&#160;million
    and $6.1&#160;million, respectively. At January&#160;1, 2006 and
    January&#160;2, 2005, the Company had accrued current
    liabilities due to Toshiba for shared research and development
    expenses of $4.2&#160;million and $5.5&#160;million,
    respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">FlashVision</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company owns 49.9% of FlashVision. The Company&#146;s
    obligations with respect to FlashVision&#146;s lease
    arrangement, capacity expansion,
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">take-or-pay</FONT>
    supply arrangements and research and development cost sharing
    are described in Note&#160;5. The fair value of the
    Company&#146;s loan to FlashVision approximates book value.
    FlashVision is a
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    F-33
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Notes to
    Consolidated Financial
    Statements&#160;&#151;&#160;(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>
<P>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    variable interest entity and the Company is not the primary
    beneficiary of FlashVision because it is entitled to less than a
    majority of any residual gains and is obligated with respect to
    less than a majority of residual losses with respect to the
    venture.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following is the summarized financial information for
    FlashVision at the Company&#146;s fiscal years ended
    January&#160;1, 2006 and January&#160;2, 2005, respectively.
    FlashVision&#146;s year-end is March&#160;31, with quarters
    ending on March&#160;31, June&#160;30, September&#160;30 and
    December&#160;31 (in thousands).

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company&#146;s maximum reasonably estimable loss exposure
    (excluding lost profits) as a result of its involvement with
    FlashVision was $298.1 and $326.0&#160;million, as of
    January&#160;1, 2006 and January&#160;2, 2005, respectively.
    These amounts are comprised of the Company&#146;s investments,
    notes receivable and contingent indemnification obligation. At
    January&#160;1, 2006 and January&#160;2, 2005, the
    Company&#146;s consolidated retained earnings included
    approximately $2.1&#160;million and $1.7&#160;million,
    respectively, of undistributed earnings of FlashVision.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Flash
    Partners</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company accounts for its 49.9% ownership position in Flash
    Partners under the equity method of accounting. The
    Company&#146;s obligations with respect to Flash Partner&#146;s
    lease arrangement, capacity expansion,
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">take-or-pay</FONT>
    supply arrangements and research and development cost sharing
    are described in Note&#160;5. Flash Partners is a variable
    interest entity and the Company is not the primary beneficiary
    of Flash Partners because it is entitled to less than a majority
    of any residual gains and is obligated with respect to less than
    a majority of residual losses with respect to the venture.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following is the summarized financial information for Flash
    Partners at the Company&#146;s fiscal years ended
    January&#160;1, 2006 and January&#160;2, 2005. The entity did
    not exist during the Company&#146;s fiscal year ended
    December&#160;28,
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    F-34
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="9%"></TD>
    <TD width="91%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Note&#160;12:&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Subsequent
    Events</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On January&#160;13, 2006, the Company completed its acquisition
    of Matrix Semiconductor, Inc., or Matrix, and acquired all of
    the outstanding stock of Matrix. The acquisition consideration
    was approximately $302&#160;million, consisting of
    3,722,591&#160;shares of common stock and approximately
    600,000&#160;shares of equity incentives valued at approximately
    $282&#160;million and $20.0&#160;million of cash, respectively.
    Matrix has pioneered the development of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">3-D</FONT> one time
    programmable integrated circuits and will be integrated into the
    Company&#146;s existing product lines. Acquisition will be
    accounted for under the purchase method. The purchase price
    allocation has not yet been finalized. As part of its
    acquisition of Matrix, the Company assumed the obligation of
    Matrix&#146;s existing facility lease totaling approximately
    $21&#160;million which will run through 2016.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In December 2005, Flash Partners entered into a master equipment
    lease agreement providing for up to 35.0&#160;billion Japanese
    yen, or approximately $297&#160;million based upon the exchange
    rate at January&#160;1, 2006, of original lease obligations.
    There were no amounts outstanding under this master lease
    agreement at the end of fiscal 2005; however, the entire amount
    was drawn down in January 2006 and the Company provided a
    guarantee for 50% of the outstanding balances, or approximately
    $148&#160;million based upon the exchange rate at
    January&#160;1, 2006. See Note&#160;5, &#147;Contractual
    Obligations and Off Balance Sheet Arrangements.&#148;
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In January 2006, the Company executed a facility lease agreement
    for a new corporate office complex to be located in Milpitas,
    California. This new corporate facility will house the
    Company&#146;s research and development, sales and marketing and
    general and administrative functions. The facility lease
    agreement runs through 2013 with the total obligation of
    approximately $19&#160;million. See Note&#160;5,
    &#147;Contractual Obligations and Off Balance Sheet
    Arrangements.&#148;
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    F-35
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

    signature appears below constitutes and appoints Eli Harari and
    Judy Bruner, jointly and severally, his or her attorneys in
    fact, each with the power of substitution, for him or her in any

    in connection therewith, with the Securities and Exchange
    Commission, hereby ratifying and confirming all that each of
    said attorneys in fact, or his or her substitute or substitutes,
    may do or cause to be done by virtue thereof.

    for the quarter ended September&#160;30, 2000.</TD>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    9. </TD>

    <TD valign="bottom">
    Previously filed as an Exhibit to the Registrant&#146;s
    Schedule&#160;13(d) dated January&#160;26, 2001.</TD>

    <BR>
    E-3
